Los Angeles County Department of Public Works, Site 7 is located at 34.668056 and -118.139167. Los Angeles

County Department of Public Works is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety

of its employees and the neighboring community. Los Angeles County Department of Public Works staff is

trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely

using chlorine.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has a long standing commitment to worker and public

safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as

personnel training, reputable contractors, and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and

maintenance of the Chlorination Process. Los Angeles County Department of Public Works policy is to

implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

As a result of the LADPW Acton and Antelope Valley Disinfection Conversion Project, the existing chlorine

treatment equipment and other accompanying work is being replaced with chloramine treatment

equipment. With this advancement, LADPW is aiming to improve the water quality by reducing the formation

of disinfection byproducts in water supplies. The disinfection byproducts such as trihalomethanes (THMs) and

haloacidic acids (HAAs) are strongly regulated by the EPA, due to their possible carcinogenic activity.

Chloramine, a more stable substitute of chlorine, is a chlorine-ammonia compound. Although chlorine is toxic

at high levels, the concentrations used in disinfecting drinking water are low enough not to pose any risks to

human health. Liquid chlorine is delivered to the facility in a one-ton container. The one-ton container is

transferred to the Chlorine ChlorTainer area by a trolley monorail system. The connected chlorine container

is within a Ch

lorTainer containment vessel. The container is connected by a yoke and adapter with new lead

gaskets within the ChlorTainer. Chlorine gas under pressure flows from the online container through a

vacuum regulator that is directly connected to each ChlorTainer. The vacuum regulator reduces the chlorine

pressure to a vacuum. The chlorine gas is suctioned out of the container using vacuum pressure generated by

a flow of pumped water. No chlorine piping or tubing is under pressure outside the ChlorTainer. One gaseous

chlorinator is installed adjacent to the ChlorTainer. The chlorinator meters and injects gaseous chlorine into

the raw water supply as it enters the Water Distribution pipeline. Chlorine is injected into the water in order

to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines. Chlorine leak

detection and warning is provided by an immediate visual detection system. Special paint is applied near

possible leak areas that turns from golden yellow to red when gas with a pH of 3 or less is present.

HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary Scenario Description:

Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst case analysis has been defined for each covered process. The results

can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the

Compliance Workbook. Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary Scenario Description:

Two alternative case release scenarios were modeled. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment

documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the Compliance Workbook.



RISK CONSIDERATIONS

Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks, and worst case release scenarios can

potentially reach the community; Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has recognized these

potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-cre

dible. In

addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make the worst case event noncredible,

it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of

the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an

event. In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential

release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a

release of a regulated substance:

The system has alarms and interlocks

The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures

Gas detection is in place to notify individuals if a leak occurs

The chlorine container is located within a locked secondary containment vessel. The vessel is tamper proof

and in the event of a release, would contain the contents of the chlorine preventing a release to atmosphere.

The facility has been subject to CalOSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) and California Accidental Release

Prevention (CalARP) Program 3 since 2008 due to the use and storage of Chlorine above the threshold of

1500 pounds and 100 pounds, respectively. Therefore the facility has been implementing a compliant Risk

Management Plan Program 3 since 2008. Increased storage to limit deliveries pushes the facility into the EPA

RMP Program.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION

The key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Los Angeles County Department of Public Works to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine. In addition,

common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being

performed; this includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute. The Chlorine Prevention

Program 3 elements include:

Process Safety Information

Process Hazar

d Analysis

Operating Procedures

Training

Mechanical Integrity

Management of Change

Pre-Startup Safety Review

Compliance Audits

Incident Investigation

Employee Participation

Hot Work Permit

Contractors

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no chlorine releases within the last five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

Los Angeles County Department of Public Works has filed a Unified Contingency Plan with Los Angeles County

Fire Department and this plan includes:

Emergency Alarm Procedures

Evacuation Procedures

Safety and Health Considerations

Notification Procedures

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and Seismic Assessment have been conducted to examine mitigation

measures to improve safety at the facility. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the reports.
